correction_response:
This tweet is misleading. While it's true that 2022 may not be the warmest year on record due to a rare triple-dip cooling La Niña, this doesn't reverse the long-term warming trend. The 10-year average for 2013-2022 is estimated to be 1.14°C above the pre-industrial baseline, compared to 1.09°C from 2011 to 2020. The last eight years have been unusually warm, exceeding 1.2C above pre-industrial levels. The long-term warming since the industrial revolution is attributable to increased concentrations of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. Looking at data over a short period in isolation can lead to misleading conclusions. The impacts of climate change, such as record ocean heat levels and rising sea levels, are becoming more dramatic.

refute_evidences: - The global mean temperature in 2022 is currently estimated to be about 1.15 [1.02 to 1.28] °C above the 1850-1900 pre-industrial average. A rare triple-dip cooling La Niña means that 2022 is likely to “only” be fifth or sixth warmest. However, this does not reverse the long-term trend; it is only a matter of time until there is another warmest year on record. Reference: https://public.wmo.int/en/media/press-release/eight-warmest-years-record-witness-upsurge-climate-change-impacts published on 2022-11-03 16:16:02

- Indeed, the warming continues. The 10-year average for the period 2013-2022 is estimated to be 1.14 [1.02 to 1.27] °C above the 1850-1900 pre-industrial baseline. This compares with 1.09°C from 2011 to 2020, as estimated by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Sixth Assessment report. Reference: https://public.wmo.int/en/media/press-release/eight-warmest-years-record-witness-upsurge-climate-change-impacts published on 2022-11-03 16:16:02

- In fact, the last eight years have been unusually warm – even warmer than expected given the long-term rate of temperature increases – with global temperatures exceeding 1.2C above pre-industrial levels. The temperature record is replete with short-term periods of slower or more rapid warming than average, driven by natural variability on top of the warming from human emissions of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. Reference: https://www.carbonbrief.org/factcheck-no-global-warming-has-not-paused-over-the-past-eight-years/ published on 2022-07-14 15:41:17

- In a rebuttal letter to the Times , Prof Richard Betts – head of climate impacts research at the Met Office Hadley Centre and University of Exeter – points out that it is “fully expected that there will be peaks of particularly high temperatures followed by a few less hot years before the next new record year”. Reference: https://www.carbonbrief.org/factcheck-no-global-warming-has-not-paused-over-the-past-eight-years/ published on 2022-07-14 15:41:17
